item.title: My Semester in Computational Biology
item.description: This is my last semester at UT Austin, and I would say that the data science skills I have learned will be useful going forward. This fall, I will be attending the Long School of Medicine at UT Health San Antonio, and I will definitely be looking into becoming involved in research. Maybe I could woo a professor by offering to help with data analysis, who knows! For most of the computational biology course, we focused on learning R for data analysis.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification

item.title: SDS348 Project 1
item.description: Introduction The two datasets I chose are “country_lit” and “country_MFI,” both of which were found on Kaggle. Country_MFI contains infant mortality rate, fertility rate, and national income per capita for every country over the years 1970-2013. It also has the region of each country. Country_lit contains the literacy rates of every country, as well as the percentage of their economy accounted for by agriculture. Part of the reason I decided to examine these datasets was to see which parts of the world were the most in the early phases of development.

item.title: SDS348 Project 2
item.description: Introduction This dataset contains information about 303 patients and is focused on conditions of the heart. The variables analyzed were age, sex (1=male, 2=female), cp(chest pain, 0=asymptomatic, 1=atypical angina, 2=non-anginal pain, 3=typical angina), fbs (fasting blood sugar, 1= >120 mg/dl, 0= <120mg/dl), restecg (resting electrocardiographic results, 0=left ventricular hypertrophy, 1=normal, 2=ST-T wave abnormality), exang (exercised enduced angina, 1=yes, 0=no), and finally, target (1=disease, 0=no disease). I altered the dataset some before analysis, first switching the 1 and 0 values of target, as 1 initially corresponded to ‘no disease’, which is counterintuitive.
